title: How to Make Chicken Piccata

steps.headline: Using a meat pounder or sharp knife, pound or cut the chicken into 1/4" thick cutlets.
steps.description: Chicken piccata should be thin, as you need to brown the outsides while allowing the inside to quickly cook as well.

steps.headline: Coat the chicken with salt and pepper.
steps.description: Use as much as you desire, making sure the entire pieces have at least a light dusting. Make sure both sides are seasoned.

steps.headline: Dredge the chicken in flour, coating completely.
steps.description: Dredging means coating it, and it should be a nice, even coating of flour. This flour will cook to form a thin, breaded coating around your chicken.

steps.headline: In a thick-bottomed pan on medium, heat up 2 tablespoons butter and 2 tablespoons olive oil.
steps.description: You could use all of one or the other, but this mixture actually has a purpose -- the two work together to keep the temperature of the oil correct while helping each other coat the chicken and, eventually, pasta. Furthermore, the richness of butter is cut by the unique, fresh taste of the olive oil, adding a new depth of flavor.

steps.headline: Cook the chicken on both sides for 3-4 minutes.
steps.description: You just want to get the outsides well-browned, but not burnt. If you didn't pound the chicken down, you'll want to turn the heat down a little and cook them slightly longer, flipping twice to ensure the middles of the chicken cook.

steps.headline: When they are golden brown, remove from skillet and cover the chicken with tin foil.
steps.description: Do not throw all the pan juices out --they are essential for the piccata sauce!

steps.headline: Keeping the pot on, deglaze the pan with a cup of white wine or lemon broth.
steps.description:
Deglazing is when cool liquid hits a hot pan, which loosens up all the flavorful burned bits on the pan's bottom to start a simple pan sauce or gravy. After the wine hits the pan, use a whisk or spatula to scrape up all the bits on the bottom of the pan, mixing them in. Note, however, that you do not have to use white wine if you don't desire:
You can also use 1/3 cup fresh lemon juice along with 2/3's cup chicken broth.

steps.headline: If not used above, add the juice of one whole lemon and 1/3 cup chicken broth to the hot wine.
steps.description: The lemon is the essential flavor in this dish, and you need to add it at some point. You can either add it to the wine as a subtle flavor, or use it to deglaze the pan along with some chicken broth for a more intense kick.

steps.headline: Add 2-3 tablespoons of fresh capers to the mixture and stir.
steps.description: Let everything cook on medium-low for a few minutes, letting the flavors meld. Now is the time to add salt and pepper as well, seasoning and tasting regularly to ensure it is coming out well.

steps.headline: Add 2 tablespoons of butter and whisk together.
steps.description: Whisk it in so that it is all melted before moving on -- it shouldn't take long.

steps.headline: Add the chicken back to the hot pan and cook together for 1-2 minutes.
steps.description: This is especially important if you're using bigger chicken breasts that may not have cooked all the way through the first time (though you should avoid this at all costs when possible). You can slice the thickest breast open to make sure it is completely cooked, if worried. If you're planning on serving the chicken later, don't add it to the sauce yet. It should be simmered to stay hot and meld flavors right before serving, as the chicken will get soggy if left in for too long. Alternatively, simply pour the sauce over the chicken if you want a crunchier coating.

steps.headline: Serve with angel hair pasta.
steps.description: A few fresh capers, a squeeze of lemon, and a dash of freshly chopped parsley would all be welcome guests on the plate as well. Top with some shaved Parmesan or Romano and you have an Italian dish worth sharing.

steps.headline: Take your chicken breasts and dip them in milk ahead of time for a thicker breading.
steps.description: The milk will give the flour a liquid to bind to, which leads to a thicker "skin" on the cooked chicken. If you do this, premix the salt and pepper in with the flour to ensure it stays on the chicken when you dredge it. The rest of the recipe proceeds like normal.

steps.headline: Add a cup of heavy cream to the sauce, stirring until well mixed, before the chicken goes back in.
steps.description: This will give a rich creaminess to the dish that the original lacks. It goes without saying that this variation is substantially heavier and less healthy than the original, but it tastes incredible.

steps.headline: Ignore the capers if you're not feeling like the olive-y bite.
steps.description: Capers are traditional in chicken piccata, but they're not for everyone. They can be easily ignored, especially if you use heavy cream (as mentioned above) to give the sauce a little more thickness and body.

steps.headline: Chop some shallots or garlic into the pan just before deglazing to add a hint of new flavors to the sauce.
steps.description: These small roots are known as aromatics. Shallots, when cooked, have a wonderful savory-sweetness, while garlic is welcome in almost all Italian dishes if you want it. Simply mince the garlic and shallots and add to the hot oil as the chicken comes out. Cook for 30-60 seconds, then proceed with the wine and/or lemon broth.

text:
Preparing the Chicken Using a meat pounder or sharp knife, pound or cut the chicken into 1/4" thick cutlets. Chicken piccata should be thin, as you need to brown the outsides while allowing the inside to quickly cook as well. Coat the chicken with salt and pepper. Use as much as you desire, making sure the entire pieces have at least a light dusting. Make sure both sides are seasoned. Dredge the chicken in flour, coating completely. Dredging means coating it, and it should be a nice, even coating of flour. This flour will cook to form a thin, breaded coating around your chicken. In a thick-bottomed pan on medium, heat up 2 tablespoons butter and 2 tablespoons olive oil. You could use all of one or the other, but this mixture actually has a purpose -- the two work together to keep the temperature of the oil correct while helping each other coat the chicken and, eventually, pasta. Furthermore, the richness of butter is cut by the unique, fresh taste of the olive oil, adding a new depth of flavor. Cook the chicken on both sides for 3-4 minutes. You just want to get the outsides well-browned, but not burnt. If you didn't pound the chicken down, you'll want to turn the heat down a little and cook them slightly longer, flipping twice to ensure the middles of the chicken cook. When they are golden brown, remove from skillet and cover the chicken with tin foil. Do not throw all the pan juices out --they are essential for the piccata sauce! Preparing the Sauce and Serving Keeping the pot on, deglaze the pan with a cup of white wine or lemon broth. Deglazing is when cool liquid hits a hot pan, which loosens up all the flavorful burned bits on the pan's bottom to start a simple pan sauce or gravy. After the wine hits the pan, use a whisk or spatula to scrape up all the bits on the bottom of the pan, mixing them in. Note, however, that you do not have to use white wine if you don't desire:
You can also use 1/3 cup fresh lemon juice along with 2/3's cup chicken broth. If not used above, add the juice of one whole lemon and 1/3 cup chicken broth to the hot wine. The lemon is the essential flavor in this dish, and you need to add it at some point. You can either add it to the wine as a subtle flavor, or use it to deglaze the pan along with some chicken broth for a more intense kick. Add 2-3 tablespoons of fresh capers to the mixture and stir. Let everything cook on medium-low for a few minutes, letting the flavors meld. Now is the time to add salt and pepper as well, seasoning and tasting regularly to ensure it is coming out well. Add 2 tablespoons of butter and whisk together. Whisk it in so that it is all melted before moving on -- it shouldn't take long. Add the chicken back to the hot pan and cook together for 1-2 minutes. This is especially important if you're using bigger chicken breasts that may not have cooked all the way through the first time (though you should avoid this at all costs when possible). You can slice the thickest breast open to make sure it is completely cooked, if worried. If you're planning on serving the chicken later, don't add it to the sauce yet. It should be simmered to stay hot and meld flavors right before serving, as the chicken will get soggy if left in for too long. Alternatively, simply pour the sauce over the chicken if you want a crunchier coating. Serve with angel hair pasta. A few fresh capers, a squeeze of lemon, and a dash of freshly chopped parsley would all be welcome guests on the plate as well. Top with some shaved Parmesan or Romano and you have an Italian dish worth sharing. Variations Take your chicken breasts and dip them in milk ahead of time for a thicker breading. The milk will give the flour a liquid to bind to, which leads to a thicker "skin" on the cooked chicken. If you do this, premix the salt and pepper in with the flour to ensure it stays on the chicken when you dredge it. The rest of the recipe proceeds like normal. Add a cup of heavy cream to the sauce, stirring until well mixed, before the chicken goes back in. This will give a rich creaminess to the dish that the original lacks. It goes without saying that this variation is substantially heavier and less healthy than the original, but it tastes incredible. Ignore the capers if you're not feeling like the olive-y bite. Capers are traditional in chicken piccata, but they're not for everyone. They can be easily ignored, especially if you use heavy cream (as mentioned above) to give the sauce a little more thickness and body. Chop some shallots or garlic into the pan just before deglazing to add a hint of new flavors to the sauce. These small roots are known as aromatics. Shallots, when cooked, have a wonderful savory-sweetness, while garlic is welcome in almost all Italian dishes if you want it. Simply mince the garlic and shallots and add to the hot oil as the chicken comes out. Cook for 30-60 seconds, then proceed with the wine and/or lemon broth. Finished.
